The development of earth-abundant catalysts with high activity and selectivity is important yet challenging in hydroformylation. In this work, a stable and efficient phosphine-oxide group containing porous organic polymer was afforded, which served as a ligand and a support to fabricate a heterogeneous Co catalyst (Co/POL-POPh3) for hydroformylation of 2-octene under mild condition. A 2-octene conversion of 94.6 % and at least three recycles were achieved using Co/POL-POPh3 in the hydroformylation with a 51.1 % aldehyde selectivity under 423 K and 3.0 MPa. The experimental and characterization results elucidated that the highly dispersed Co ions was coordinated with the phosphine-oxide groups in the polymer, which was beneficial for the 2-octene isomerization and in turn led to the excellent performance for synthesis of oxygenates. Furthermore, a reaction mechanism was also suggested for 2-octene hydroformylation over the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst. The current study delivers valuable insights into the adjustment of the catalytic efficiency of non-previous metal catalysts in the heterogeneous hydroformylation of internal olefins. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co-based catalysts Phosphine-oxide group Porous organic polymers Hydroformylation of 2-octene Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydroformylation reaction is considered as an industrially important process applied for the production of aldehydes and related products [1-3]. These products are widely applied in higher-value solvents, plasticizers, detergents, and surfactants production [4]. To date, only the Rh/phosphine, Co/phosphine, or ligand-free systems are employed in industrial application. In particularly, Rh/phosphine catalysts have found widespread use in the hydroformylation of shorter chain alkenes under mild reaction conditions, showing excellent activity and selectivity towards linear aldehydes [5,6]. However, owing to their high cost, limited reserve and the issue of catalyst separation of the aforementioned Rh metal, significant recent concerns have been raised about the inexpensive and abundant Co-based catalysts, which still occupy a dominant position in industrial processes for long-chain terminal and internal olefins [7]. Nevertheless, industrialized Co-based catalysts still suffer from inherent limitations in lower activity, poor selectivity, difficult separation and harsh reaction conditions. Therefore, the exploration of highly efficient heterogeneous Co-based catalysts has attracted more and more attention from researchers. One possible solution is to immobilize active metal Co or Co molecular complex on the solid supports, such as SiO2 [8-11], activated carbon [12,13], β-Mo2C [14,15], molecular sieve [16-18], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [19], inorganic oxides [12,20,21], through physical and chemical interactions. Other method is the concept of atomically dispersed metal atoms catalysts, which are a very promising technique to bridge homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis due to the maximum atomic utilization efficiency [15,22]. Despite these advancements, it is attractive to improve the activity and selectivity of Co-based catalyst especially by the criterion of rhodium's catalytic performance. Porous organic polymers (POPs), possessing tunable pore sizes and architectures, high surface areas, exceptional thermal and chemical stability, and chemical modularity, have garnered considerable research interest. As one of the most effective supports, a series of POPs based on phosphine ligands have been constructed by vinyl solvothermal polymerization [23-27]. However, the majority of the above phosphine-containing POPs are used as supports and ligands for preparing effective Rh catalysts. For instance, our research team has synthesized a porous organic ligands (POLs) supported single Rh sites catalysts (Rh/POL-PPh3), which exhibited good performance in olefins hydroformylation and other reactions. Owing to the existence of phosphorous, the carrier POL-PPh3 is easy to be oxidized, probably resulting in a potential deactivation of the catalyst. Conversely, phosphine oxides have attracted much attention because it might tend to facilitate the insertion of carbon monoxide in metal alkyl complexes [28]. Based on this merit, different types of catalysts containing phosphine oxides ligands are constructed for the hydroformylation of olefins. For example, many phosphine oxide ligands have been developed in homogeneous Rh and Co catalyzed hydroformylation of higher olefins [29-32]. In addition, He and coworkers found a Co-Ph3PO/PDMS/SiO2 catalysts had good catalytic activity and stability for mixed isomeric octenes hydroformylation [10]. To our knowledge, controlling the isomerization rate between the internal and terminal olefin performed for the catalysts plays significant roles in determining the targeted hydroformylation of internal olefins to yield linear aldehydes and alcohols. In this work, a stable and inexpensive phosphine oxides-containing porous organic polymer was designed and synthesized, which was employed as a ligand and a support to bind to cobalt (denoted as Co/POL-POPh3). In order to take advantage of the strong isomerization ability of phosphine-modified cobalt catalyst system, 2-octene was regarded as a model substrate to test the catalytic performance of afforded Co/POL-POPh3 catalysts. Comprehensive characterization showed that the highly dispersed Co ions was coordinated with the phosphine-oxide groups in the polymer. The catalytic performance of resultant Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst is superior to that of inorganic carrier-loaded Co catalysts. Moreover, the effects of reaction temperature, pressure and reaction time on catalytic performance were systematically investigated and the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst could be reused at least for three cycles. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals The 2-octene (98 %) was purchased commercially from Aladdin. The Co(OAc)2 was procured from Macklin. A commercial SiO2 and Al2O3 support materials were purchased from Qingdao Haiyang Chemicals Plant. The H2O2 (30 %) was obtained from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Company®. Toluene (99 %) and tetrahydrofuran (99 %) were distilled over sodium under nitrogen flow. 2.2 Methods 2.2.1 Synthesis of catalysts POL-PPh3 was prepared by following the previously reported method [24]. 2.2.1.1 Synthesis of POL-POPh3 Generally, 200 mg of POL-PPh3 was suspended in 10 mL of CH2Cl2 in a three-neck flask under N2 flow and then 30 % H2O2 (4 × 2 mL) was added in batches. The resulting mixture was stirred for 5 h at room temperature and the formed suspension was filtered out, washed with water and acetone. The obtained white solid was dried at 358 K for 5 h under vacuum, denoted as POL-POPh3. 2.2.1.2 Synthesis of Co/POL-POPh3 The Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst was prepared using an impregnation method similar to a previous work [33]. Typically, 68.8 mg Co(OAc)2 was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol under nitrogen flow. The resulting solution was stirred for 30 min and then 0.2 g of POL-POPh3 was dispersed into the solution under stirring for 24 h at room temperature. Then, the light pink solid was filtered, washed several times with excess of ethanol and dried at 353 K for 5 h under vacuum, labeled as Co/POL-POPh3. The theoretic content of cobalt in the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst was 10 wt%, while the real value was accurately determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) analysis. For comparison, Co/SiO2 and Co/Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized in the same way using the SiO2 and Al2O3 as the support materials, Co(OAc)2 as the precursors and ethanol as the solvent. The loading content of cobalt in Co/SiO2 and Co/Al2O3 catalysts was also accurately determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) analysis (Table S6). 2.2.2 Material characterization Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were performed on SPECTRUM 3 instrument in a wavenumber range of 500–4000 cm–1. The sample was putted into tablet press to produce thin wafer with a diameter of 1 cm. A HTG-1 thermal analyzer was used to perform the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments in a flow of nitrogen at 20 mL min–1 from 303 K to 1073 K with a heating rate of 10 K min−1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis were collected by a PANalytical EMPYREAN powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154056 nm) in the 2θ range between 3° to 85 °at a scanning rate of 8° min–1. The nitrogen physisorption isotherms were taken on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 at 77 K. Before measurements, the samples were outgassed at 120 °C for 12 h. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) methods were employed to calculate the specific surface areas and the pore size distribution curves, respectively. Pore volume was derived at the P/P0 of 0.995. A JEM-2100 instrument was used to acquire transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (120 kV). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) were recorded with a Sigma-500 (0.01–30 kV) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed by a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi and the reference C 1s peak at 284.6 eV was employed to calibrate the binding energy. The Solid-state 31P and 13C MAS NMR spectra were carried out on a VARIAN Infinity plus spectrometer. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) analysis was conducted on an Anton Paar Multiwave 3000 system. 2.2.3 Catalytic activity tests The hydroformylation of 2-octene was performed in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave. A typical catalyst evaluation procedure was as follows: 1.8 g of 2-octene, 24.6 mg of Co/POL-POPh3 and 9.0 g of toluene were added into the autoclave with a magnetic stirrer. Then, syngas (CO:H2 = 1: 1) was employed to purge the autoclave three times and the autoclave was pressurized with syngas to 3.0 MPa at room temperature. Thereafter, the autoclave was heated to 423 K for 4 h with constant stirring. After the completion of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled in an ice bath and the pressure was slowly released. The reaction mixture in the autoclave was separated by filtration or centrifugation and identified by gas chromatography (Agilent 7890A, HP-5 column, FID detector) using n-propanol as internal standard. The recycling experiments of the catalyst were performed in the same autoclave and tested by centrifugation, which was reused for the next run after washing three times with degassed toluene. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 FTIR studies As illustrated in Scheme 1 , POL-POPh3 support was easily synthesized by the oxidation of POL-PPh3 with the aid of 30 % H2O2. To verify the successful transformation, the FT-IR spectra of POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 was shown in Fig. 1 a and b. The peaks at 2926, 2853 and 1404 cm–1 can be ascribed to the symmetric, asymmetric stretching and bending vibration of the -CHCH2- moieties in the polymer skeleton [34,35]. The adsorption bands at 1600, 1498, and 1448 cm−1 can be ascribed to CC stretching vibration from the aromatic rings. Besides, the characteristic bands of the PO group at 1186 cm−1 was observed in the polymer skeleton, suggesting the successful oxidization of POL-PPh3 polymers [36-38]. Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst was synthesized by impregnation of POL-POPh3 support with Co(OAc)2 complex in a certain amount of ethanol. The chemical composition of the Co/POL-POPh3 were also determined by FT-IR. The FT-IR spectra of Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst was almost the same as the POL-POPh3 support (Fig. 1a), which proved that the structure of POL-POPh3 did not change after Co species anchoring. Furthermore, Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst showed a strong vibration band at 619 and 567 cm–1. The absorption band at 619 cm−1 could be assigned to the Co(OAc)2 complex, suggesting the Co(OAc)2 precursor was successfully loaded on the POL-POPh3 carriers (supporting information, Fig. S1). The weak absorption band at 567 cm−1 could be attributed to the the formation of Co-O species [38-40], indicating that the existence of interactions between the Co species and phosphine oxide groups in the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst. 3.1.2 XRD and TG study The thermal stability of materials is a key factor for acting as support in heterogeneous catalyst field. TG analysis (Fig. 1c) turned out that POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 material started to decompose as the temperature reached 450 ºC, indicating their excellent thermal stability, which favors potential application in heterogeneous catalysis at low temperature. The XRD patterns (Fig. 1d) of the POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 demonstrates the amorphous nature of the support and catalyst [31]. No obvious characteristic peaks of cobalt nanoparticles were observed in XRD patterns of Co/POL-POPh3, revealing that the Co species are well dispersed in the polymers. 3.1.3 BET characterization The textural properties of POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 was systematically investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption experiments shown in Table 1 and Fig. 2 . It was found that both the BET surface areas and pore volume of the POL-POPh3 reduced from 957 m2 g−1 to 646 m2 g−1 and 2.2 cm3 g−1 to 1.5 cm3 g−1 after metallization with Co species, respectively, suggesting that the presence of abundant Co species at its pore in the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2a, the isotherms of POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 exhibited a steep increase in the regions with 0.80 < P/P0 < 1.0 and P/P0 < 0.01, indicating that the existence of macropores and micropores. While a hysteresis loop in the P/P0 > 0.6 region was deduced from mesopores, also reflecting that POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 had a graded porous property. Consistently, pore size distribution plots calculated from NLDFT methods (Fig. 2b) showed that the pore size distribution of POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 ranges from 0 nm to 85 nm, further confirming POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 contained hierarchically porous structure that favors the exposure of active sites. 3.1.4 Morphology and microstructure characterization The morphology, pore structure and dispersion of Co species in Co/POL-POPh3 were characterized through SEM and TEM analysis. The morphology of typical POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 was clearly visualized in SEM images (Fig. 3 a–d), which exhibited the rough and amorphous structure with ample pores, further indicating that the presence of hierarchical porosity in the polymer skeleton. This hierarchical porosity structure played a key role in easy access to active PO groups sites and fast mass transfer between gas -phase reactants and the interior of catalyst particles. The TEM images of Co/POL-POPh3 (Fig. 3e and f) displayed that Co ions were well distributed in POL-POPh3. Furthermore, SEM-EDS elemental mappings revealed that all the functional elements (C, P, O and Co) were uniformly distributed in the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst. This is further evidence that the hierarchical porosity structure and the high surface area of Co/POL-POPh3 are conducive to exposing more PO group coordination sites, which facilitates the uniform dispersion and anchoring of metals. 3.1.5 13C and 31P MAS NMR characterization The 13C MAS NMR spectrum analysis were employed to determine the local structure of POL-POPh3 polymer and Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst (Fig. 4 a). The signal at 42.2 ppm corresponds to the polymerized vinyl groups in the backbone of polymer, suggesting the successful polymerization of 3v-PPh3. A quite small peak at 113 ppm can be attributed to vinyl groups, indicating the high degree of polymerization of the POL-POPh3 carrier. The signal at around 132.3 ppm resulted from the carbon signals of all aromatic group rings in the polymer. The 13C MAS NMR spectra of POL-POPh3 polymer reveals the chemical shift is analogous to that observed in the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst, confirming the integrity of their backbone after cobalt loading. Moreover, the 31P NMR spectra of POL-POPh3 support exhibit just one peak at 26.6 ppm (Fig. 4b), which is identical to that of phosphine oxide moieties. Compared with POL-POPh3, Co/POL-POPh3 shows a relatively high-field peak at 27.3 ppm, which can be assigned to the PO moieties coordinated with cobalt sites. The result is also confirmed via FT-IR and XPS. 3.1.6 XPS characterization The surface chemical composition and chemical state of the components of POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 were defined by XPS analysis. The P 2p spectrum (Fig. 5 a) of POL-POPh3 carrier displayed two peaks located at 131.8 eV and 132.8 eV that could be assigned to P-C and PO bonds [37], respectively. While P 2p peaks (Fig. 5b) located at 132.8 eV of Co/POL-POPh3 shifted to a lower binding energy (132.5 eV) after Co loading, indicating that PO bond coordinated with cobalt successfully. The downshift of binding energy in the O 1s spectra for Co/POL-POPh3 compared to the POL-POPh3 support was observed (Fig. 5d and e), also suggesting that the coordination of O atoms with Co(OAc)2 fragments via PO groups of POPh3 ligands [41]. The XPS spectrum of Co 2p electrons yielded two main peaks positioned at 781.5 eV (Co 2p3/2) and 797.4 eV (Co 2p1/2) along with two satellites, which could be assignable to Co2+ ion and the coordination of cobalt ion with the PO moieties in POL-POPh3 polymer [16,22,42,43]. These results give strong evidence that there is a powerful interplay between PO groups and Co (II) species in the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst. Furthermore, the XPS survey scan of POL-POPh3 and Co/POL-POPh3 confirms the presence of C, O, P and Co (Fig. 5f). The loading Co content in Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst was measured to be 6.72 wt% by ICP-OES. 3.2 Catalytic performance evaluation It is commonly recognized that the P(OPh)3 ligands-modified cobalt catalyst system have strong isomerization ability [10]. As a consequence, the 2-octene hydroformylation was empolyed as a representative reaction to assess the performance of the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst. Initially, the catalytic properties of different kinds of catalysts were assessed for the 2-octene hydroformylation. As shown in Table 2 , the conversion of 2-octene was only 2.7 % and no aldehydes and alcohols were formed over the POL-POPh3 support, suggesting that 2-octene was mainly transformed into alkane and iso-alkenes by POL-POPh3. With the introduction of Co(OAc)2, the conversion of 2-octene and the selectivity of oxygenates containing aldehydes and alcohols were increased to 94.6 % and 55.2 % on Co/POL-POPh3, respectively. Moreover, the aldehyde and alcohol l/b ratio of 0.8 and 0.9 were attained by Co/POL-POPh3, respectively. For comparison, some other inorganic materials supported Co catalysts were prepared and measured, such as Co/SiO2 and Co/Al2O3. It could be found that the oxygenates selectivity on Co/POL-POPh3 was better than those on the conventional loaded catalysts (Co/SiO2 and Co/Al2O3). And the l/b ratio of aldehyde on Co/POL-POPh3 was much higher than those on Co/Al2O3 catalysts. Obviously, the excellent catalytic properties of Co/POL-POPh3 can be ascribed to its unique structure and the coordination between Co species and P(OPh)3 ligands via the PO moieties in the polymer skeleton. In addition, the homogeneous catalyst Co-POPh3 and Co(OAc)2 were tested at the same condition. The molar ratio of Co(OAc)2 to P(OPh)3 ligand was set to 0.5. Apart from the selectivity of aldehydes, it suffered from lower 2-octene conversion and alcohols selectivity for Co/POL-POPh3 compared to the homogeneous analogues, mainly owing to the dispersion degree of Co active sites limited by the skeleton structure of POPs. However, l:b ratio of aldehydes and alcohols over Co/POL-POPh3 were superior to its homogeneous analogues, which clearly manifested that the framework structure of POPs could increase the steric hindrance of Co–PO active species analogous to homogeneous system. Next, by considering the investigated processing conditions, temperature preference is one of the essential means to regulate catalyst properties. As shown in Fig. 6 a, under 120 and 140 °C, the conversion of 2-octene was very low and only isomeric olefins are the converted products. There were no aldehydes and alcohols formation, indicating that lower temperature was beneficial to isomerization for Co/POL-POPh3 catalysts. The conversion of 2-octene and the selectivity of oxygenates were improved significantly when the temperature was increased from 140 to 150 °C. However, at higher temperatures (160 and 180 °C), the conversion of 2-octene, the selectivity of oxygenates and l/b ratio decreased significantly (Fig. 6a and Table S2). The pressure of syngas was also screened from 1.0 to 4.0 MPa at 150 °C. Similar to the effect of temperature, no aldehydes or alcohols were formed in lower syngas pressure (Fig. 6b). It is worthwhile to notice that the high syngas pressure would result in a higher oxygenates selectivity and a lower selectivity of iso-alkenes and alkane. Furthermore, higher pressures led to a decease of l:b ratio of aldehydes and increase of l:b ratio of alcohols (Fig. 6b and Table S3). The 2-octene conversion and oxygenates selectivity were 98.8 % and 85.3 %, respectively, when the pressure of syngas was increased to 4.0 MPa. With regard to the efficiency and safety production, a milder pressure of 3.0 MPa was selected for further investigations. Furthermore, the reaction time was investigated between 2.0 and 24 h under 150 °C and a syngas pressure of 3.0 MPa (Fig. 6c). Within the first 2 h, a 2-octene conversion of 88.7 % and oxygenates selectivity of 30.7 % were obtained, indicating that the isomerization of 2-octene was the main reaction process. It is obvious that the 2-octene conversion and oxygenates selectivity were increased when prolonging the reaction time from 2 to 24 h, while the l/b ratio of aldehydes and alcohols decreased gradually (Fig. 6c and Table S4). An excellent 2-octene conversion of 95.7 % and oxygenates selectivity of 63.5 % were acquired when the reaction time was further increased up to 24 h. Remarkably, 2-octene conversion and oxygenates selectivity increased slowly after 4 h. Therefore, the maximum 2-octene conversion was measured as 94.5 % when the temperature reached 150 °C under 3.0 MPa syngas (CO/H2 = 1) for 4 h catalyzed by Co/POL-POPh3. Recyclability plays a critical role for catalysts performance. As demonstrated in Fig. 6d, recycling experiments displayed that the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst can be reused at least three cycles with only a slight loss in activity and selectivity. As shown in Table S5, a total of 6.7 wt% of the Co species was leached to the liquid phase during the three recycles, indicating that insignificant leaching of Co under the reaction conditions. On the other hand, the initial mass of the catalyst for the cycle experiment was 24.6 mg, while it was 16.1 mg after three cycle reaction. Therefore, the slight decrease of catalytic activity may be due to the slightly metal Co leaching and inevitable weight loss in the step of separation. The catalytic performance of a series of other reported homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts has been compared with that of Co/POL-POPh3 (Table 3 ). The 2-octene conversion of porous organic polymer supported Rh catalysts is slightly lower, but they have high l/b ratio of aldehyde (entry 2 and 3). Some other catalysts deliver high aldehyde yield but low l/b ratio of aldehyde (entry 4, 5 and 7). Some catalysts achieve both high aldehyde yield and l/b ratio with high costs (entry 6). These comparison results show that Co/POL-POPh3 has quite high efficiency for 2-octene hydroformylation. 3.3 Mechanism of 2-octene hydroformylation over Co/POL-POPh3 The mechanism of alkene hydroformylation catalyzed by carbonyl Co catalyst has been proposed by Heck and Breslow in 1960s [51], which has been widely accepted [52,53]. Inspired by the homogeneous reaction mechanism, a plausible mechanism for the 2-octene hydroformylation using Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst is speculated, which is shown in Fig. 7 . During the catalysis process, Co species are prone to coordinate with the PO groups in the Co/POL-POPh3 polymer frame, which might form the pseudo-tetrahedral structure of the complexes (Fig. S3) based on prior research involving triphenyl phosphine oxide ligands [38,54,55]. The corresponding pre active species HCo(CO)3(PO-frame) (1) is possibly formed in the presence of syngas owing to ligands polymer spatial structure limitation[56]. Initially, the cobalt hydride tricarbonyl species (1) fastly dissociate a CO molecule (2) and then involve 2-octene or 1-octene addition to a cobalt hydride to form the π complex (3), which determines the formation of the linear or branched alkyl-cobalt intermediates. After that the acyl-cobalt species (5) are provided by migratory insertion of a CO molecule to Co–C bonds in alkyl-cobalt intermediates. Finally, acyl-cobalt species undergoes a H2 oxidative addition, giving rise to nonanal products and regenerating the cobalt-hydride species. As regards the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst, cobalt coordinated with electron-donating PO groups in the polymer skeleton made it more electron-rich, which, in turn leads to difficult CO dissociation. Based on the reaction data, it is verified that Co/POL-POPh3 is a very active alkene isomerization catalyst. Therefore, the coordination between the cobalt and PO group in the polymer skeleton made it an effective isomerization catalyst, which effectively converted 2-ocetene hydroformylation to aldehydes. 4 Conclusion In summary, a stable and inexpensive phosphine oxides-containing porous organic polymer was prepared by a solvothermal polymerization-oxidation synthesis strategy, which was employed as a ligand and a support to develop a new type of Co-based catalyst (Co/POL-POPh3) for hydroformylation of 2-octene. Under the optimized experimental conditions, the Co/POL-POPh3 showed 94.6 % conversion of 2-octene with aldehyde selectivity of 51.1 % and could be reused for three times with high efficiency. Experimental investigations and characterization results indicated that the Co (II) species were strongly coordinated with the highly accessible PO sites of the POL-POPh3 support, thus endowed the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst with good activity and selectivity in hydroformylation of 2-octene. Benefiting from its simple operability and low cost, it is very promising for Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst to realize the large-scale industrial applications. This work provides a new perspective for hydroformylation of internal olefins and preparing heterogeneous catalysts approximating homogeneous activity. Further application of efficient porous organic polymer supported Co-based catalysts in hydroformylation of olefins is in progress in our laboratory. coredata.dc:description: The development of earth-abundant catalysts with high activity and selectivity is important yet challenging in hydroformylation. In this work, a stable and efficient phosphine-oxide group containing porous organic polymer was afforded, which served as a ligand and a support to fabricate a heterogeneous Co catalyst (Co/POL-POPh3) for hydroformylation of 2-octene under mild condition. A 2-octene conversion of 94.6 % and at least three recycles were achieved using Co/POL-POPh3 in the hydroformylation with a 51.1 % aldehyde selectivity under 423 K and 3.0 MPa. The experimental and characterization results elucidated that the highly dispersed Co ions was coordinated with the phosphine-oxide groups in the polymer, which was beneficial for the 2-octene isomerization and in turn led to the excellent performance for synthesis of oxygenates. Furthermore, a reaction mechanism was also suggested for 2-octene hydroformylation over the Co/POL-POPh3 catalyst. The current study delivers valuable insights into the adjustment of the catalytic efficiency of non-previous metal catalysts in the heterogeneous hydroformylation of internal olefins.
